awd_titl_txt: III: Small: Mining Heterogeneous Network Built from Multiple Data Sources to Reduce Opioid Overdose Risks
awd_abstract_narration:
As opioid overdose deaths have continued to increase over the past decade across the country, it is critical to understand the drugs involved in those deaths and the potential role of polypharmacy (i.e., the concurrent use of multiple medications) in opioid overdose deaths. However, due to the formidable complexity of drug-drug interactions (DDIs) arising from polypharmacy, it is challenging if not impossible to count them all manually. Therefore, there is an urgent need for developing novel computational methodologies and models for early detection of risky DDI patterns when opioids are combined with other drugs (e.g., sedatives, muscle relaxants, anti-anxieties). Since relying on a single data source for biomedical knowledge discovery often results in unsatisfactory performance, the goal of this project is to design and develop a novel and integrated framework (algorithms, models, and techniques) to construct a heterogeneous network built from multiple data sources and extract useful information from the constructed network to reduce the risk of opioid overdoses resulting from polypharmacy. 

The key components of the planned research are three-folds. First, the research team will construct a heterogeneous network from multiple data sources for abstract representation. Second, the team will develop scalable techniques for large-scale and dynamic heterogeneous network representation learning. Third, the team will design a novel deep learning framework with interpretability enhancement for early detection of risky DDI patterns when opioids are combined with other medications. The broad impacts of this work include benefits to the general public by addressing one of the most challenging issues facing U.S. public health today (i.e., overdose death prevention). The planned research in this project is also beneficial to the intelligent information management domain where multiple data sources are involved. The project integrates interdisciplinary research with education through curriculum development, the participation of underrepresented groups, and student mentoring activities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Opioid addiction has become one of the largest and deadliest epidemics in the United States (US). The White House has insisted that battling the opioid epidemic is an "urgent priority": 10.1 million Americans reported misusing opioids in 2019; an estimated 108,000 drug overdose deaths in the US in 2021, 90% of which involved opioids. This points to an imminent need to understand the drugs involved in those deaths and the potential role of polypharmacy (referring to the concurrent use of multiple medications) in opioid overdose deaths. However, due to the formidable complexity of drug-drug interactions (DDIs) arising from polypharmacy, it is challenging if impossible to count them all manually. To address this challenge, this project aims to design and develop a novel yet holistic framework to construct a heterogeneous network built from multiple data sources and extract useful information from the constructed network to reduce the risks of opioid overdose resulting from polypharmacy. With partial support of this grant, during the project period, the team has had 71 publications (including 2 Ph.D. dissertations) in recognized journals (e.g., IEEE TBD, IEEE TKDE, ACM TIST, ACM TKDD, etc.) and in proceedings of highly competitive conferences with acceptance rate about or less than 20% (e.g., ICML'2023, CIKM'2021-2023, AAAI'2019, 2021-2023,  AMNLP'2022, SIAM SDM'2022, IJCAI'2019-2022, SIGKDD'2021-2022, NeurIPS'2021-2022, WWW'2021 etc.). The research outcomes have been widely disseminated to research communities and practitioners through the publications, presentations, seminars, project website and demos, media presses, etc. Specially, with partial support of this project, the PI and her team have received the AAAI-DCAA 2023 Best Paper Runner-Up Award, the SIGKDD 2022 Best Paper Award Shortlist (Research Track), the prestigious ACM CIKM 2021 Best Paper Award (Full Paper Track), and the ACM CIKM 2021 Best Paper Award Runner Up (Applied Paper Track), and the WWW 2021 Best Paper Award Shortlist.

By probing into the cause of opioid overdose deaths, the proposed techniques and developed systems in this project have provided novel insights to new approaches of combating the epidemic at different levels (patients, physicians and communities). The proposed research will be beneficial to the general public by addressing one of most challenging issues facing US public health today. This work on the combat against the opioid crisis has generated significant societal impacts, which was promoted by the Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA) and aired on NBC and the stadium during the Notre Dame football game with millions of audiences in the "Red Robbin Week" in 2023. In addition to the significant societal impact, the research in this project is also beneficial to the Information Integration and Informatics (III) community when large-scale, multi-source, multi-modal data is involved. This project is a showcase of demonstrating how computer and health scientists can reach out to each other's field and collaboratively work toward a scientific understanding of opioid overdose crisis. Developing advanced computational tools for epidemiology and public health research is likely to have increasingly more impact as technology keeps moving forward. Advances in data science, AI and machine learning will reshape the landscape of public health research - e.g., they may support real-time epidemiology in the coming future. The outcomes of this project (including open-source code and benchmark) have been made publicly accessible; and broadly distributed through publications, presentations, seminars, demonstrations, etc. The project has integrated research with education through curriculum development, K-12 outreach activities and engaging postdocs, graduate and undergraduate students in research. The project has also increased the involvement of underrepresented groups, including minority and women (e.g., four females have involved in working on AI and data driven research related to this project).
